results.content:
I will happily give it a 5/5 so far. The content is very well made and the tutorials are short, consistent and well explained.

I would suggest to have a somewhat familiarity with a blockchain and JS before starting the course as this could be somewhat advanced in some areas, or at least it does not always covers all the theory behind it. However I had taken another vary basic course on blockchain before this with python and this is a great step-up from there

results.content: I first took the original class, and it was great, but in the end, I learned it was just an introduction. So I signed up for the 10 times more expensive full class. Only to learn that it is a total rewriting and I now must spend the first 6 hours +++ to go through the same stuff again. Only this time it a bit different here and there. There is no path that explains ONLY THE DIFFERENCES, and then I see the front end is a disappointing dummy. So this entire class is an expensive waste, and I totally lost all inspiration...

response.content: Sections 10-11 cover this subject. Throughout various lectures in these two sections, the frontend interacts with the backend to get the blockchain blocks, post new transactions, mine new blocks, etc. I would encourage going through there, and posting in the Q&A if you have any questions!

results.content:
Almost over 60%, this is my first 5 star course. 
1. The author dive into code in 10min w/o bullshit.
2. The project is very practical & useful, makes you look good on resume.
3. jest unit testing driven, very very practical experience like in industry

Only 1 suggestion, it would be good if we can save transaction data in database, that would be the awesome improvement.
results.content_html:
Almost over 60%, this is my first 5 star course.
1. The author dive into code in 10min w/o bullshit.
2. The project is very practical & useful, makes you look good on resume.
3. jest unit testing driven, very very practical experience like in industry

Only 1 suggestion, it would be good if we can save transaction data in database, that would be the awesome improvement.

results.content:
The concept is amazing. The project is awesome. You don't just learn about blockchain but a lot more including javascript, react, TDD, Heroku deployment.
That being said there was a very little explanation about the blockchain concepts. There should have been more graphical explanation. Also, the instructor is too fast.
But overall, I enjoyed the course and it was worth the money!
results.content_html:
The concept is amazing. The project is awesome. You don't just learn about blockchain but a lot more including javascript, react, TDD, Heroku deployment.
That being said there was a very little explanation about the blockchain concepts. There should have been more graphical explanation. Also, the instructor is too fast.
But overall, I enjoyed the course and it was worth the money!

results.content: It was great learning experience, i learned a lot about the backend part of a crypto currency but you cannot use it for a real production alt coin. You don't have access to your own private keys and the front end web wallet/website only works on your own ip address, so its kinda useless. The React portion is outdated and should be using functional components and hooks instead classes.
results.content_html: It was great learning experience, i learned a lot about the backend part of a crypto currency but you cannot use it for a real production alt coin. You don't have access to your own private keys and the front end web wallet/website only works on your own ip address, so its kinda useless. The React portion is outdated and should be using functional components and hooks instead classes.

results.content: This course is no longer supported, the versions of plugins used are vastly outdated and updated versions are incompatible, the approach to this is very poor as you will write then rewrite the code multiple times as he takes you through each little bug you might encounter rather than just saying we are writing this to counter x y z and saving hours of rework. Then to make matter worse after spending all this time to build the blockchain and publish, turns out it all exists in memory so the moment the server turns off it is all gone. Unless you are an experienced programmer that can figure out how to store that data in a local file and make the server check the file on startup all you have here is a game.
results.content_html: This course is no longer supported, the versions of plugins used are vastly outdated and updated versions are incompatible, the approach to this is very poor as you will write then rewrite the code multiple times as he takes you through each little bug you might encounter rather than just saying we are writing this to counter x y z and saving hours of rework. Then to make matter worse after spending all this time to build the blockchain and publish, turns out it all exists in memory so the moment the server turns off it is all gone. Unless you are an experienced programmer that can figure out how to store that data in a local file and make the server check the file on startup all you have here is a game.

results.content: You could insist a bit more on the explanations, theory, probably add more diagrams, longer more descriptive lessons, besides the actual coding.
results.content_html: You could insist a bit more on the explanations, theory, probably add more diagrams, longer more descriptive lessons, besides the actual coding.

results.content: Good course to get the fundamentals of building within Node.  The course instructor is a whiz at this topic yet has so much to teach that some of the students call is a rap concert.  Meaning he is rolling through the course without stopping to really explain the concepts.  If you are truly just here to type out the code to get a blockchain then you are in the right place.  If you are here to learn node, reddis, and what it will take to maintain the blockchain then maybe you need to start somewhere else.  I have made it to the end after watching the lecture and typing what I saw only to find that I am terrified to go back in and try to customize things.  Not a good feeling and not very useful if you ask me.
results.content_html: Good course to get the fundamentals of building within Node. The course instructor is a whiz at this topic yet has so much to teach that some of the students call is a rap concert. Meaning he is rolling through the course without stopping to really explain the concepts. If you are truly just here to type out the code to get a blockchain then you are in the right place. If you are here to learn node, reddis, and what it will take to maintain the blockchain then maybe you need to start somewhere else. I have made it to the end after watching the lecture and typing what I saw only to find that I am terrified to go back in and try to customize things. Not a good feeling and not very useful if you ask me.

Should have design documents and visualization

results.content:
The backend part of the course is really good. I learned a lot about blockchain there and also about node.js.
2 stars reduction for:
- the frontend part is only valuable if you have good knowledge of web development, react, etc. If not, it is basically watching David code and  redo what he does without much learning experience.
- the course seems not to be supported anymore. Questions are not answered. That, in my opinion, is a significant issue which reduces the value significantly.
results.content_html:
The backend part of the course is really good. I learned a lot about blockchain there and also about node.js.
2 stars reduction for:
- the frontend part is only valuable if you have good knowledge of web development, react, etc. If not, it is basically watching David code and redo what he does without much learning experience.
- the course seems not to be supported anymore. Questions are not answered. That, in my opinion, is a significant issue which reduces the value significantly.

There were some bugs occurred but those were fixable by googling.  Overall satisfactory course.

results.content:
I believe it's the most complete course on the entire Internet. Much better than other courses I took. I give 4 stars instead of 5 because I want to push the instructor to also create a fully decentralized and distributed blockchain. Truly challenging but I am sure the lecturer is a very smart person.
Oh did I mention that I received answers to my questions on 31st December and 1st January? TRULY AMAZING EXPERIENCE. I am sure I will be referring to this course every time I need and use it as a model!

Edit: What I meant by fully decentralized and distributed is a Blockchain that is not dependent on the server. If you close the Redis server the blockchain dies. Therefore, a fully decentralized Blockchain would be able to implement a peer to peer communication protocol through TCP + peer discovery protocol. Just like Bitcoin ;)
results.content_html:

I give 4 stars instead of 5 because I want to push the instructor to also create a fully decentralized and distributed blockchain. Truly challenging but I am sure the lecturer is a very smart person.
Oh did I mention that I received answers to my questions on 31st December and 1st January? TRULY AMAZING EXPERIENCE. I am sure I will be referring to this course every time I need and use it as a model!

Edit: What I meant by fully decentralized and distributed is a Blockchain that is not dependent on the server. If you close the Redis server the blockchain dies. Therefore, a fully decentralized Blockchain would be able to implement a peer to peer communication protocol through TCP + peer discovery protocol. Just like Bitcoin ;)

results.content:
This course is pretty thorough as far as coding goes. He keeps it simple, goes step by step, and starts out only working in the root so you don't have any problem keeping a map in your head about what goes where and what is related to what. 

The test-driven approach is completely new to me, so that's a hurdle to get over. It's starting to make sense, though I wish there was more foundational lessons leading up to it. What you do is build a test for a particular part of your program, thenfill in the blanks in the code to get the tests to work one by one. It makes wonderful sense, can speed the coding, and the suite he uses (jest), really zeros in on the errors. But you have to wrap your head around it, and if you don't know JS, you won't be able to do a lot of coding without help. In principle, it looks like a powerful approach that will probably pay dividends in the future.

However, he moves so fast that it sometimes lacks clear, in depth explanation of the underlying theory, and you have to go back and study the code to see what's going on, if you even can. I think the only reason I can keep up so far is that I've already learned Ruby and Solidity and there are a lot of similarities with JS, and I have some layman's background in blockchain. The delivery is a little over-enthusiastic for my tastes, but his knowledge and skill as a coder are indisputable. What's more, he can translate that into understandable language for beginners.

Overall, it's a very good course so far, but I would advise those without any programming experience to get a basic course down first before undertaking this. The other option is to skip ahead and do his Java Script review first which comes later in the course.

UPDATE: Raising from 4 to 4.5 stars. Appears I started at a bad time, while David was on sabbatical. So it took months to solve an issue with the test sweet. But now he's back and answering questions regularly and promptly. I got passed my problem, and am now rockin' and rollin'. He even inserted a couple of new lectures on PubNub so Windows users don't get bogged down in Redis installation and configuration. Really propels you through that section. Took only one day to get a fully functioning and synchronized blockchain once back on course.  Fantastic!
results.content_html:
This course is pretty thorough as far as coding goes. He keeps it simple, goes step by step, and starts out only working in the root so you don't have any problem keeping a map in your head about what goes where and what is related to what.

The test-driven approach is completely new to me, so that's a hurdle to get over. It's starting to make sense, though I wish there was more foundational lessons leading up to it. What you do is build a test for a particular part of your program, thenfill in the blanks in the code to get the tests to work one by one. It makes wonderful sense, can speed the coding, and the suite he uses (jest), really zeros in on the errors. But you have to wrap your head around it, and if you don't know JS, you won't be able to do a lot of coding without help. In principle, it looks like a powerful approach that will probably pay dividends in the future.

However, he moves so fast that it sometimes lacks clear, in depth explanation of the underlying theory, and you have to go back and study the code to see what's going on, if you even can. I think the only reason I can keep up so far is that I've already learned Ruby and Solidity and there are a lot of similarities with JS, and I have some layman's background in blockchain. The delivery is a little over-enthusiastic for my tastes, but his knowledge and skill as a coder are indisputable. What's more, he can translate that into understandable language for beginners.

Overall, it's a very good course so far, but I would advise those without any programming experience to get a basic course down first before undertaking this. The other option is to skip ahead and do his Java Script review first which comes later in the course.

UPDATE: Raising from 4 to 4.5 stars. Appears I started at a bad time, while David was on sabbatical. So it took months to solve an issue with the test sweet. But now he's back and answering questions regularly and promptly. I got passed my problem, and am now rockin' and rollin'. He even inserted a couple of new lectures on PubNub so Windows users don't get bogged down in Redis installation and configuration. Really propels you through that section. Took only one day to get a fully functioning and synchronized blockchain once back on course. Fantastic!

A week ago I took the original crash course of this series and I reviewed it with 4.5 stars. This remastered version is better and I feel it deserves 5 stars, as the code is improved, it gets a bit closer to a realistic application, especially now, a front end is developed as well.

Thanks for the instructor.

results.content:
Well, I really thought it would have been a complete ready system that could handle real transaction on a crypto/token newly created. Well, instead it's just an exercise! It would have been great to have more details about linking to Metamask wallet or else for this to be a real case app! This course needs some serious updates for it and certainly rebuild it with recent dependencies to avoid warnings and critical issues.
I really hope this "full stack" course will be completed by another one to make this app reflect it's title "Build a Blockchain and CRYPTOCURRENCY" that it's actually missing!

results.content:
I am in the middle of the course, and I absolutely in love with the topic and the way instructor teaches. The test driven approach is really awesome. 

I would suggest one thing that the course contains much of practical part. Around 80%. Although you have covered most of the basics, theory section looks very less. You may add some theory as real world examples.

 Also you can put some quizzes at the end of the each section.

Also, you should create a zip file to share your code. I found really difficult to correct my mistakes in the code by simply reading at screen.

Overall, excellent. 4.5 stars because, there is always scope of improvement. Hence cutting the half star for further motivation.

response.content:
Thanks for the feedback and suggestions! As noted in the necessary reading from the first section, the code is actually all available at the github course repository: https://github.com/15Dkatz/cryptochain

I agree that it's hard to bebug solely based on the screen, so the above resource should help ?
response.content_html:
Thanks for the feedback and suggestions! As noted in the necessary reading from the first section, the code is actually all available at the github course repository: https://github.com/15Dkatz/cryptochain

Also you can put some quizzes at the end of the each section.

Also, you should create a zip file to share your code. I found really difficult to correct my mistakes in the code by simply reading at screen.

Overall, excellent. 4.5 stars because, there is always scope of improvement. Hence cutting the half star for further motivation.

results.content: The course was great and David the instructor was very articulate and informative and extremely fast to respond to requests for help. However I would have liked it to finish with advising on how to give other users a simple wallet that they can then be a part of my currency. There was no information on how to distribute this to other players in my game. I don't feel that each user should have to build this entire system on their computers, so how does it distribute?
results.content_html: The course was great and David the instructor was very articulate and informative and extremely fast to respond to requests for help. However I would have liked it to finish with advising on how to give other users a simple wallet that they can then be a part of my currency. results.content: This course helped a lot to understand cryptocurrencies. I learnted test-driven development and jest library. Front-end part could be more comprehensive  though.
results.content_html: This course helped a lot to understand cryptocurrencies. I learnted test-driven development and jest library. Front-end part could be more comprehensive though.

results.content:
Great course!!!!
Thank you David.

I've missed  three things:
1.- What happens when the size of the block chain is too large to send  it as a simple message?
2.- A peer 2 peer protocol. Redis is not bad, but you need to install one in each node to avoid centralization. It results in a mega cluster.
3. and above all a consensus algorithm for the aproval of new blocks.

Could you add information links on how to implement these features, please?

Thank you in advance.
results.content_html:
Great course!!!!
Thank you David.

I've missed three things:
1.- What happens when the size of the block chain is too large to send it as a simple message?
2.- A peer 2 peer protocol. Redis is not bad, but you need to install one in each node to avoid centralization. It results in a mega cluster.
3. and above all a consensus algorithm for the aproval of new blocks.

Could you add information links on how to implement these features, please?

Thank you in advance.
